linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the country-wide EOR screening study, Raudhatain Zubair (RAZU) was identified as a potential ASP (Alkaline Surfactant Polymer) EOR target. The Raudhatain field is located in North Kuwait and it consists of multiple stacked sand stone reservoirs (Figure 1). This field was discovered in 1955 and has been on continuous production since 1960 (Abdul Azim et. al., 2006). The RAZU formation is the deepest of three major oil producing reservoirs in the large dome anticline (Nemcsok et. al., 2006).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Raudhatain Zubair Main Reservoirs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Raudhatain Zubair Main Reservoirs

linkTarget.anchoringText: Aerially the reservoir was divided into 6 sectors as shown in Figure 2 below. A semi-quantitative approach was chosen to rank each of the 6 areas for suitability of pilot execution. The selection criteria incorporated a detailed look at STOIIP and remaining oil for EOR, waterflood maturity and sweep efficiency, oil production and water cut, formation properties, sample availability for laboratory calibration, representativeness of area for full-field application, well density, faults and compartmentalization, surface facilities congestion and surface facilities readiness to receive ASP produced oil. Due to the higher density of faults and higher surface footprint in the southern and western quadrants of the field, the decision was taken to select the pilot location in Areas 1 and 2 of Figure 2 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Raudhatain Zubair Areal Division into Sectors

formatted-caption.caption-text: Raudhatain Zubair Areal Division into Sectors

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Raudhatain Zubair field is highly dissected by many faults (over 36 main faults). Most of the faults are concentrated on the southern and western quadrants of the field as shown in Figure 3 below. In general, very few faults are connected. However, this doesn’t eliminate the risk of compartmentalization with respect to the sub seismic faults since the stratigraphic sequence contains high density of shale streaks. A small fault throw can disconnect the sands and create baffles due to juxtaposition or shale smearing along the fault surface.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Areal distribution of faults in Raudhatain Zubair Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Areal distribution of faults in Raudhatain Zubair Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fluid movements in the reservoir are impacted greatly by relative permeabilities. Available SCAL data as shown in Figure 4 below was reviewed and compared with the relative permeabilities from the previously history-matched KOC Eclipse model. Due to the limited Relative Permeability SCAL data available from RAZU UZSD, Shell proprietary tool “RELATE” was used to generate relative permeability ranges based on Shell’s analog sandstone database for similar formations in Middle East region. However, in the end the decision was made to stay with measured SCAL data from the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Available SCAL data and parameter range for UZSD

formatted-caption.caption-text: Available SCAL data and parameter range for UZSD

linkTarget.anchoringText: Large volume blocks (volume modifiers) were attached to the edge of the model and the volume of these blocks was adjusted so that the pressure decline in the model was consistent with the range of average pressure decline observed in the field (Shell Generation 1 Model Report). It was expected that during the pilot injection period, the injector and producers of the pilot would dominate the pressure profile in the pattern. This was verified on running the sector model at the injection and production rates specified for the pilot. This method reduced the effort that it would have taken to get a complete history match for the simulation model to set the pressure boundary conditions. Figure 5 depicts location of volume modified blocks and plane along which pressure across producers and injector is plotted in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Location of volume modified blocks and plane along producer and injector for pressure profile

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of volume modified blocks and plane along producer and injector for pressure profile

linkTarget.anchoringText: Large volume blocks (volume modifiers) were attached to the edge of the model and the volume of these blocks was adjusted so that the pressure decline in the model was consistent with the range of average pressure decline observed in the field (Shell Generation 1 Model Report). It was expected that during the pilot injection period, the injector and producers of the pilot would dominate the pressure profile in the pattern. This was verified on running the sector model at the injection and production rates specified for the pilot. This method reduced the effort that it would have taken to get a complete history match for the simulation model to set the pressure boundary conditions. Figure 5 depicts location of volume modified blocks and plane along which pressure across producers and injector is plotted in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Pressure across producers (left) and injector (right), reference case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure across producers (left) and injector (right), reference case

linkTarget.anchoringText: The current average pressure of Upper Zubair Sand in Areas 1 and 2 of UZSD Zubair 46 channel (Z46CH) area is estimated to be around 3625 psia. This is based on the available Static BHP and Repeat Formation Tester (RFT) data. As shown in Figure 7 below, the annual pressure drop in the pilot area historically ranged from 5.2 psia/year to 39.3 psia/year. Based on this understanding, the sector model was initialized at 3625 psi and boundary conditions were applied such that average pressure drop per year was stable between 5.2 and 39.3 psia/year as shown in Figure 7 below. A sensitivity analysis was performed to evaluate impact of different pressure decline rates on the model which showed minimal impact of pressure decline on incremental recovery from ASP.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Various volume modifiers applied in the model to capture range of average pressure decline rate of 5.2-39.3 psi/year as observed in the field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Various volume modifiers applied in the model to capture range of average pressure decline rate of 5.2-39.3 psi/year as observed in the field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The left panel of Figure 8 below shows oil saturation in a layer representing the average oil saturation for the sector model at the start of brine pre-flush. The model indicates that oil saturation at the pilot injection well location could be approximately 45-65% in some intervals or higher in less swept intervals of the Z46CH sand of UZSD. The right panel of the Figure shows oil saturation in the same model layer after 1.5 years of pre-flush brine injection into the pilot injection well, with oil saturation in a significant faction of the pattern reaching value of ~ 30%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Oil saturation at start of brine pre-flush (left) and after 1.5 years of brine pre-flush (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil saturation at start of brine pre-flush (left) and after 1.5 years of brine pre-flush (right)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil saturation at start of brine pre-flush

linkTarget.anchoringText: The left panel of Figure 9 below shows oil saturation in the same model layer as shown in Figure 8 above at the start of ASP injection (thus right pane of Figure 8 is replicated as left pane of Figure 9). The right pane of Figure 9 shows the oil saturation after one year of injecting 0.3 PV ASP followed by polymer chase flood. Mobilization of the waterflood remaining oil can be observed in the model. This phenomenon is highly dependent on the chemical slug performance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Oil saturation at start of chemical flood i.e. at the end of brine pre-flush (left) and after one year of 0.3 PV of chemical injection and polymer chase injection (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil saturation at start of chemical flood i.e. at the end of brine pre-flush (left) and after one year of 0.3 PV of chemical injection and polymer chase injection (right)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil saturation at start of chemical flood i.e. at the end of brine pre-flush
after one year of 0.3 PV of chemical injection and polymer chase injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The idealized pattern recovery factor and average oil saturation in the pattern after ASP flood is shown in Figure 10 below. It can be observed from the results that oil saturation in the pilot area reduces to Sorw (i.e. 30%) within 1.5 years of pre-flush water injection. After 0.3 PV of chemical injection and chasing slug with polymer, oil saturations were reduced to around 5% in the pilot pattern area within another 1.5 years. This prediction is an ultimate recovery based on top quartile chemical performance and low areal heterogeneities due to small pilot pattern size.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Reference case desaturation of oil and pattern recovery factor

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reference case desaturation of oil and pattern recovery factor

linkTarget.anchoringText: Response of oil production due to ASP injection is shown in Figure 11 below. Reduction in water cut is due to oil bank reaching the pilot producers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Pilot Location Pattern ASP response – Optimistic Reference Case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pilot Location Pattern ASP response – Optimistic Reference Case

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this simulation study, the average oil saturation of 57% over the Z46CH layer was used, which was estimated as shown in Figure 12 below from 2013 Pulse Neutron Lifetime (PNL) log of RA-0106 well in the pilot area. An additional 10% was added and reduced from the average saturation for the low and high cases modeled in the simulation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Well logs and Histogram of current oil saturation based on 2013 data for Well RA-0106

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well logs and Histogram of current oil saturation based on 2013 data for Well RA-0106

linkTarget.anchoringText: The relative permeability curves for ASP slug propagation through the reservoir and the values for residual oil saturation to chemical (Sor*) were derived from a statistical analysis of data in the Shell Global Chemical EOR database. Figure 13 below illustrates the high medium and low range of relative permeability parameters used for the ASP slug.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Relative permeability High, Mid, Low curves derived from the Shell Global Chemical EOR Database

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative permeability High, Mid, Low curves derived from the Shell Global Chemical EOR Database

linkTarget.anchoringText: To mimic the effect of fluid drift in the simulation model, pseudo-injectors and pseudo-producers were used to create fluid drift from East to West. The range of pressure gradients that might be observed in the field was taken from was Figure 7.Figure 14 below illustrates how oil desaturation occurs in a preferred direction if pilot is situated near existing producers, injectors or aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Oil de-saturation after 0.3 PV ASP injection for reference case with no fluid drift (left) and with fluid drift from East to West (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil de-saturation after 0.3 PV ASP injection for reference case with no fluid drift (left) and with fluid drift from East to West (right).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil de-saturation after 0.3 PV ASP injection for reference case with no fluid drift
fluid drift from East to West

linkTarget.anchoringText: The impact of key uncertainties was evaluated by generating a Tornado plot using parametric analysis for the simulation model. The tornado plot illustrates the variation of incremental oil recovery for an ASP flood and is shown in Figure 15 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Tornado plot showing impact of key uncertainties over reference case on Incremental oil recovery factor from ASP

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tornado plot showing impact of key uncertainties over reference case on Incremental oil recovery factor from ASP

linkTarget.anchoringText: Surfactant propagation is a key issue in assessing performance of an ASP project and in it can be anticipated that the larger the pattern size the less efficient is the surfactant propagation. Minimizing the time to evaluate pilot performance became a driver in for the project. Different pilot pattern sizes were evaluated to assess the effect of heterogeneity on performance. The oil desaturation and oil recovery for the pilot pattern sizes evaluated is shown in Figure 16 below. For a 0.5-1.5 Acre inverted 5-spot pattern, average oil saturation of the pattern is reduced to less than 10% within one year after 0.3 PV ASP injection followed by polymer chase injection. In the larger pattern spacing (i.e. 7.5 Acre pattern) average oil saturation reduces to only 20% over a similar period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Oil Desaturation Comparison – Pattern Size

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Desaturation Comparison – Pattern Size

linkTarget.anchoringText: For purpose of this modeling work, ratio of cumulative oil to cumulative water injected after start of ASP injection was used as a proxy to oil chemical ratio. Oil chemical ratio for various pattern sizes is shown in Figure 17 below. As expected, it can be observed that smaller the pattern size, the faster the incremental gain in oil recovery from the chemical injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Pattern size

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Pattern size

linkTarget.anchoringText: The regular versus inverted five spot patterns were evaluated for the ASP pilot design. The inverted 5-spot pattern consists of 4 producers surrounding 1 injector in the middle whereas the regular 5-spot has 4 injectors surrounding 1 central producer as shown in Figure 18 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Regular five spot and inverted five spot patterns

formatted-caption.caption-text: Regular five spot and inverted five spot patterns

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil desaturation comparison for the two pattern types is shown in Figure 19 below, depicting average oil saturation reducing to 10% for the regular 5-spot pattern in comparison to 6% in inverted 5 spot in similar time duration with similar volumes and rates of fluid injected. Balancing total injection and production is necessary to maintain voidage in a pilot with an unconfined pattern. (As opposed to a confined inverted 5 spot pattern where production is four times that of injection due to no flow across the pattern boundaries).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Oil Desaturation comparison – Pattern Type

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Desaturation comparison – Pattern Type

linkTarget.anchoringText: To understand the efficiency of pattern types, Oil chemical ratios for regular and inverted 5-spot patterns were compared as shown Figure 20 below. It can be observed that the Inverted 5-spot pattern is more efficient in mobilizing the oil from the pilot area to the producers compared to regular 5-spot pattern for similar volumes and rates of fluid injected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Pattern type

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Pattern type

linkTarget.anchoringText: This can be explained further by comparison of the oil desaturation after ASP slug injection for both pattern types as shown in Figure 21 below. The inverted 5-spot pattern shows higher desaturation than the regular 5-spot pattern in the pilot pattern area, mainly due to injection lost to area outside the pilot for the regular 5-spot pattern.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Oil desaturation after ASP slug injection for Inverted five spot pattern (left) and Regular five spot pattern (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil desaturation after ASP slug injection for Inverted five spot pattern (left) and Regular five spot pattern (right)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil desaturation after ASP slug injection for Inverted five spot pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: Injection rate or injection volume per year is a measure of the speed at which pattern area is being swept. The range of injection/production rates that was evaluated for the pilot pattern was 500 bpd to 5000 bpd with 1600 bpd as reference case (Voidage Replacement Ratio, VRR=1). For low injection rate of 500 bpd, oil desaturation is very slow. For the high injection rate of 5000 bpd, oil saturation is quite rapid reducing to almost 5% within 1 year after ASP slug was injected. The comparison of oil desaturation is shown in Figure 22 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Oil desaturation Comparison – Injection Rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil desaturation Comparison – Injection Rate

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Injection Rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Injection Rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: Injecting too much polymer will not continue to improve the displacement efficiency for a given pore volume injected. Figure 24 below shows that there is a noticeable reduction in remaining oil saturation on increasing the viscosity of the slug from 1 cP to 2 cP. However, the upside going from 2 cP to 6 cP is not very significant and there is no upside in going from 6 cP to 10 cP so far as lowering the remaining oil saturation in the pattern is concerned. This would support a decision to begin designing the insitu polymer slug viscosity close to 2 cP.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Oil Desaturation Comparison – Polymer Viscosity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Desaturation Comparison – Polymer Viscosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: The cumulative oil chemical ratio improves when polymer viscosity is increased, as shown in Figure 25 below. However, as discussed above, this comes at the cost of an injectivity decrease when the injection fluid is more viscous. Thus, designing for an ASP injection slug viscosity in the range of 2-6 cP is recommended.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative Oil Chemical Ratio – Effect of ASP slug Viscosity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative Oil Chemical Ratio – Effect of ASP slug Viscosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the reference case, pore volume of injected ASP slug is 0.3 PV. This chemical slug size was varied from a low case of approximately 0.1 PV to the high case of 0.6 PV. The oil desaturation for the different cases is illustrated in Figure 26 below and is consistent with general experience in Enhanced Oil Recovery.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Oil Desaturation Comparison – ASP slug size

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Desaturation Comparison – ASP slug size

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil desaturation and oil chemical ratios for a small ASP slug size and a large ASP slug size are compared in Figure 27 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – ASP Slug Size

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – ASP Slug Size

linkTarget.anchoringText: The chemical concentration of the ASP slug is specified relative to the optimal concentration used in the reference case. The surfactant concentration is varied from a value that is one tenth of the reference case to a value that is ten times that of the reference case. The lower the chemical concentration or under optimal, the higher the interfacial tension, which results in a lower mobilized water flood residual oil. This is the reason for the significant downside in oil recovery when less surfactant is injected in the ASP slug. The oil desaturation as a function of surfactant concentration injected and the corresponding oil/chemical ratio is as shown in the Figures 28 and 29 respectively below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Oil desaturation comparison, Surfactant concentration

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil desaturation comparison, Surfactant concentration

linkTarget.anchoringText: The chemical concentration of the ASP slug is specified relative to the optimal concentration used in the reference case. The surfactant concentration is varied from a value that is one tenth of the reference case to a value that is ten times that of the reference case. The lower the chemical concentration or under optimal, the higher the interfacial tension, which results in a lower mobilized water flood residual oil. This is the reason for the significant downside in oil recovery when less surfactant is injected in the ASP slug. The oil desaturation as a function of surfactant concentration injected and the corresponding oil/chemical ratio is as shown in the Figures 28 and 29 respectively below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Surfactant concentration in ASP slug

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Chemical ratio comparison – Surfactant concentration in ASP slug

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 30 below shows notional location of observation/sampling wells in the RAZU pilot pattern. Although eight notional locations are shown, only 2 or 3 observation/sampling wells will be drilled to aid data acquisition and surveillance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: Notional location of observation/sampling wells in the RAZU pilot pattern.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Notional location of observation/sampling wells in the RAZU pilot pattern.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The left side of Figure 31 below shows a plot of permeability variation with depth extracted from the model for the areal location corresponding to Obs-1 in Figure 30 above. The right side of Figure 31 below shows the arrival times of brine3 (injection brine) at Obs-1 well for different permeability layers. As expected, the breakthrough of the injection brine (brine3) occurs rapidly for the higher permeability layers, while it takes a very long time for the injection brine to break through for the lower permeability layers in the model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: Pre-flush Arrival time at Obs-1 well in the model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pre-flush Arrival time at Obs-1 well in the model.
